ref: 12588 śr̥ṅgavēra n. ʻ dried or fresh ginger ʼ Suśr. [Pop. etym., from horn -- like shape of the root, for (Pa.) siṅgi -- vēra -- (← Drav. Tam. iñci ʻ ginger ʼ, &c. DED 363, and Tam. vēr ʻ root ʼ, &c. DED 4554: T. Burrow BSOAS xi 130). Ultimate origin of the first element was in SEAsia, F. W. Thomas JRAS 1905, 169. Further to the name and its subsequent history see A. S. C. Ross, Ginger (Oxford 1952)]
Pa. siṅgivēra -- n. (siṅgĭ̄ -- f.) ʻ ginger ʼ,

lang: Language of `Kharoṣṭhī Inscriptions discovered by Sir Aurel Stein in Chinese Turkestan' edited by A. M. Boyer, E. J. Rapson, and E. Senart
